content.sentence: To facilitate patient care in emergency situations, the system must be interoperable with other hospital systems in a time critical manner.
content.parserSentence: To facilitate patient care in emergency situations, the system must be interoperable with other hospital systems in a time critical manner.

content.sentence: In order to support interoperability with other hospital systems, for such tasks as medication or other order entry the system should be able to, in a time critical manner, receive an account number from the hospital ADT system, or alternatively, generate an account number in concert with the hospital system.
content.parserSentence: In order to support interoperability with other hospital systems, for such tasks as medication or other order entry the system should be able to, in a time critical manner, receive an account number from the hospital ADT system, or alternatively, generate an account number in concert with the hospital system.

content.sentence: 1) The system shall provide the ability to receive an account number from the hospital or other ADT system, before additional identifying data is known.
content.parserSentence: The system shall provide the ability to receive an account number from the hospital or other ADT system, before additional identifying data is known.

content.sentence: 2) The system may generate a temporary account number for emergent orders and other interoperability need, in the absence of an account number from the hospital or other ADT system.

content.sentence: EDC.1.1.2.3 – ED  ED Merge Registration
content.parserSentence: EDC.1.1.2.3 – ED  ED Merge Registration

content.sentence: Statement: Merge the record begun in the EDIS with the formal registration in an ADT system.
content.parserSentence: Statement: Merge the record begun in the EDIS with the formal registration in an ADT system.

content.sentence: Description: In the EDIS environment, the EDIS is rarely used to capture full demographic or financial data.
content.parserSentence: Description: In the EDIS environment, the EDIS is rarely used to capture full demographic or financial data.

content.sentence: Instead, a hospital or other ADT system is used to capture this data which is then transferred or linked to the EDIS along with the account number generated for the visit.
content.parserSentence: Instead, a hospital or other ADT system is used to capture this data which is then transferred or linked to the EDIS along with the account number generated for the visit.

content.sentence: A method needs to exist to perform this transaction.
content.parserSentence: A method needs to exist to perform this transaction.

content.sentence: An automated ADT merge is preferable, minimizing the administrative burden.
content.parserSentence: An automated ADT merge is preferable, minimizing the administrative burden.

content.sentence: 1) The system shall provide a means to capture data from the hospital ADT system.
content.parserSentence: The system shall provide a means to capture data from the hospital ADT system.

content.sentence: 2) The system should merge registrations automatically based upon certain rules.

content.sentence: 3) The system shall provide a means to manually merge registrations if automated merge fails or is not employed.
content.parserSentence: The system shall provide a means to manually merge registrations if automated merge fails or is not employed.

content.sentence: Description: External sources are those outside the EHR system, including clinical, administrative, and financial information systems, other EHR systems, PHR systems, and data received through health information exchange networks.

content.sentence: Statement:  Incorporate clinical data and documentation from external sources
content.parserSentence: Statement:  Incorporate clinical data and documentation from external sources

content.sentence: Description: Mechanisms for incorporating external clinical data and documentation (including identification of source) such as image documents and other clinically relevant data are available.
content.parserSentence: Description: Mechanisms for incorporating external clinical data and documentation (including identification of source) such as image documents and other clinically relevant data are available.

content.sentence: Data incorporated through these mechanisms is presented alongside locally captured documentation and notes wherever appropriate.

content.sentence: Description: Triage is the most fundamental process in emergency department care.

content.sentence: Not the collection of data on arriving patients, but the categorization and prioritization of patients who are unable to be seen immediately.

content.sentence: Unless an ED has unlimited resources, some patients will invariable need to wait.

content.sentence: An EDIS should support the management of these patients by displaying them and supporting decisions by the providers who are caring for them.

content.sentence: Description: Possible order entry support includes, but is not limited to: notification of missing results required for the order, suggested corollary orders, notification of duplicate orders, institution specific order guidelines, guideline-based orders or order sets, order sets, order reference text, patient diagnosis specific recommendations pertaining to the order.

content.sentence: Also, warnings for orders that may be inappropriate or contraindicated for specific patients (e.g. X-rays for pregnant women) are presented.

content.sentence: 1) The system shall identify required order entry components for non-medication orders

content.sentence: 4) The system should automatically answer or pre- populate the answers to questions required for diagnostic test ordering from data within the medical record or captured during the encounter.

content.sentence: Statement: Evaluate results and notify provider of results within the context of the patient’s healthcare data.

content.sentence: Description: Possible result interpretations include, but are not limited to: abnormal result evaluation or notification, trending of results (such as discrete lab values), evaluation of pertinent results at the time of provider order entry (such as evaluation of lab results at the time of ordering a radiology exam), evaluation of incoming results against active medication orders.

content.sentence: In most EDIS implementations, the laboratory system generally handles critical alerts.

content.sentence: Description: Entry of specific patient conditions may lead to recommendations for referral.

content.sentence: DC.2.4.5.1 Support  for Safe Blood Administration
content.parserSentence: DC.2.4.5.1 Support  for Safe Blood Administration

content.sentence: Statement: Provide checking in real-time for potential blood administration errors.
content.parserSentence: Statement: Provide checking in real-time for potential blood administration errors.

content.sentence: Description: To reduce errors at the time of blood product administration, the patient is positively identified.

content.sentence: Additionally, checks on blood product identification, amount to be delivered, route and time of administration are captured, and alerts are provided as appropriate.
content.parserSentence: Additionally, checks on blood product identification, amount to be delivered, route and time of administration are captured, and alerts are provided as appropriate.

content.sentence: DC.2.4.5.2 Support  for Accurate Specimen Collection
content.parserSentence: DC.2.4.5.2 Support  for Accurate Specimen Collection

content.sentence: Statement: Provide checking in real-time to ensure accurate specimen collection is supported.
content.parserSentence: Statement: Provide checking in real-time to ensure accurate specimen collection is supported.

content.sentence: Description: To ensure the accuracy of specimen collection, the patient and specimen are positively identified.
content.parserSentence: Description: To ensure the accuracy of specimen collection, the patient and specimen are positively identified.

content.sentence: The provider is notified in real-time of potential collection errors such as wrong patient, wrong specimen type, wrong means of collection, wrong site, and wrong date and time.

content.sentence: 1) The system shall provide the ability to present information necessary to correctly identify the patient and accurately identify the specimen to be collected including, but not limited to, patient name, specimen type, specimen source, means of collection, date and time.
content.parserSentence: The system shall provide the ability to present information necessary to correctly identify the patient and accurately identify the specimen to be collected including, but not limited to, patient name, specimen type, specimen source, means of collection, date and time.

content.sentence: 2) The system shall report variation between the type of specimen order placed and actual specimen received.

content.sentence: DC.2.6 Support  for Population Health

content.parserSentence: DC.2.6.1 Support  for Epidemiological Investigations of Clinical Health Within a Population.

content.sentence: Statement: Support internal and external epidemiological investigations of clinical health of aggregate patient data for use in identifying health risks from the environment possibly and possibly population in accordance with jurisdictional law
content.parserSentence: Statement: Support internal and external epidemiological investigations of clinical health of aggregate patient data for use in identifying health risks from the environment possibly and possibly population in accordance with jurisdictional law

content.sentence: Description: Standardized surveillance performance measures that are based on known patterns of disease presentation can be identified by aggregating data from multiple input mechanisms.
content.parserSentence: Description: Standardized surveillance performance measures that are based on known patterns of disease presentation can be identified by aggregating data from multiple input mechanisms.

content.sentence: For example, elements include, but are not limited to patient demographics, resource utilization, presenting symptoms, acute treatment regimens, laboratory and imaging study orders and results and genomic and proteomic data elements.
content.parserSentence: For example, elements include, but are not limited to patient demographics, resource utilization, presenting symptoms, acute treatment regimens, laboratory and imaging study orders and results and genomic and proteomic data elements.

content.sentence: Identification of known patterns of existing diseases involves aggregation and analysis of these data elements by existing relationships.
content.parserSentence: Identification of known patterns of existing diseases involves aggregation and analysis of these data elements by existing relationships.

content.sentence: However, the identification of new patterns of disease requires more sophisticated pattern recognition analysis.
content.parserSentence: However, the identification of new patterns of disease requires more sophisticated pattern recognition analysis.

content.sentence: Early recognition of new patterns requires data points available early in the disease presentation.
content.parserSentence: Early recognition of new patterns requires data points available early in the disease presentation.

content.sentence: Demographics, ordering patterns and resource use (e.g., ventilator or intensive care utilization pattern changes) are often available earlier in the presentation of non-predictable diseases.

content.sentence: Consumer-generated information is also valuable with respect to surveillance efforts.

content.sentence: 1) The system shall provide the ability to aggregate patient information based on user-identified criteria.

content.sentence: 3) The system should provide the ability to use any demographic or clinical information as criteria for aggregation
content.parserSentence: The system should provide the ability to use any demographic or clinical information as criteria for aggregation

content.sentence: 4) The system should present aggregate data in the form of reports for external use
content.parserSentence: The system should present aggregate data in the form of reports for external use

content.sentence: 5) The system should provide the ability to save report definitions for later use.
content.parserSentence: The system should provide the ability to save report definitions for later use.

content.sentence: 6) The system may present aggregate data in an electronic format for use by other analytical programs.

content.sentence: DC.2.7 Support  for Knowledge Access
content.parserSentence: DC.2.7 Support  for Knowledge Access

content.sentence: DC.2.7.1 Access Healthcare Guidance
content.parserSentence: DC.2.7.1 Access Healthcare Guidance

content.sentence: Statement: Provide pertinent information from available evidence-based knowledge, at the point of care, for use in healthcare decisions and care planning.
content.parserSentence: Statement: Provide pertinent information from available evidence-based knowledge, at the point of care, for use in healthcare decisions and care planning.

content.sentence: Description: The information available regarding disease, disease processes, diagnostic testing, pharmaceuticals, treatment patterns and all aspects of healthcare is constantly changing.
content.parserSentence: Description: The information available regarding disease, disease processes, diagnostic testing, pharmaceuticals, treatment patterns and all aspects of healthcare is constantly changing.

content.sentence: The practitioner should be able to access a wide variety of sources that provide relevant, accurate information about any given subject.
content.parserSentence: The practitioner should be able to access a wide variety of sources that provide relevant, accurate information about any given subject.

content.sentence: Examples of resources include, but are not limited to: evidence on treatment of specific medical conditions, maintenance specific medical conditions, maintenance of wellness, drug or device trials, context specific information available through online journals, printed resources such as books and specialty organizations resources.
content.parserSentence: Examples of resources include, but are not limited to: evidence on treatment of specific medical conditions, maintenance specific medical conditions, maintenance of wellness, drug or device trials, context specific information available through online journals, printed resources such as books and specialty organizations resources.

content.sentence: For example, when a condition is diagnosed the provider might be directed to relevant resources that give updated clinical research, useful pharmaceutical combinations, surgical techniques, products or other information useful in the management of the specific condition under consideration.
content.parserSentence: For example, when a condition is diagnosed the provider might be directed to relevant resources that give updated clinical research, useful pharmaceutical combinations, surgical techniques, products or other information useful in the management of the specific condition under consideration.

content.sentence: 1) The system shall provide the ability to access evidence based healthcare recommendations, with documentation of sources.
content.parserSentence: The system shall provide the ability to access evidence based healthcare recommendations, with documentation of sources.

content.sentence: 2) The system should provide the ability to access evidenced-based documentation appropriate for the care provider to render a timely judgment.
content.parserSentence: The system should provide the ability to access evidenced-based documentation appropriate for the care provider to render a timely judgment.

content.sentence: 3) The system may provide the ability to access external evidence-based documentation.

content.sentence: 4) The system should support interoperability with knowledge bases or guidelines deployed in an enterprise.

content.sentence: DC.3 Operations Management and Communication
content.parserSentence: DC.3 Operations Management and Communication

content.sentence: DC.3.1 Clinical  Workflow Tasking
content.parserSentence: DC.3.1 Clinical  Workflow Tasking

content.sentence: Statement: Schedule and manage tasks with appropriate timeliness.
content.parserSentence: Statement: Schedule and manage tasks with appropriate timeliness.

content.sentence: Description: Since the electronic health record will replace the paper chart, tasks that were based on the paper artifact must be effectively managed in the electronic environment.
content.parserSentence: Description: Since the electronic health record will replace the paper chart, tasks that were based on the paper artifact must be effectively managed in the electronic environment.

content.sentence: Functions must exist in the EHR-S that support electronically any workflow that previously depended on the existence of a physical artifact (such as the paper chart, a phone message slip) in a paper based system.
content.parserSentence: Functions must exist in the EHR-S that support electronically any workflow that previously depended on the existence of a physical artifact (such as the paper chart, a phone message slip) in a paper based system.

content.sentence: Tasks differ from other more generic communication among participants in the care process because they are a call to action and target completion of a specific workflow in the context of a patient's health record (including a specific component of the record).
content.parserSentence: Tasks differ from other more generic communication among participants in the care process because they are a call to action and target completion of a specific workflow in the context of a patient's health record (including a specific component of the record).

content.sentence: Tasks also require disposition (final resolution).
content.parserSentence: Tasks also require disposition (final resolution).

content.sentence: The initiator may optionally require a response.
content.parserSentence: The initiator may optionally require a response.

content.sentence: For example, in a paper based system, physically placing charts in piles for review creates a physical queue of tasks related to those charts.
content.parserSentence: For example, in a paper based system, physically placing charts in piles for review creates a physical queue of tasks related to those charts.

content.sentence: This queue of tasks (for example, a set of patient phone calls to be returned) must be supported electronically so that the list (of patients to be called) is visible to the appropriate user or role for disposition.
content.parserSentence: This queue of tasks (for example, a set of patient phone calls to be returned) must be supported electronically so that the list (of patients to be called) is visible to the appropriate user or role for disposition.

content.sentence: Tasks are time-limited (or finite).
content.parserSentence: Tasks are time-limited (or finite).

content.sentence: The state transition (e.g. created, performed and resolved) may be managed by the user explicitly or automatically based on rules.
content.parserSentence: The state transition (e.g. created, performed and resolved) may be managed by the user explicitly or automatically based on rules.

content.sentence: For example, if a user has a task to signoff on a test result, that task should automatically be marked complete by the EHR when the test result linked to the task is signed in the system.
content.parserSentence: For example, if a user has a task to signoff on a test result, that task should automatically be marked complete by the EHR when the test result linked to the task is signed in the system.

content.sentence: Patients will become more involved in the care process by receiving tasks related to their care.
content.parserSentence: Patients will become more involved in the care process by receiving tasks related to their care.

content.sentence: Examples of patient related tasks include acknowledgement of receipt of a test result forwarded from the provider, or a request to schedule an appointment for a pap smear (based on age and frequency criteria) generated automatically by the EHRS on behalf of the provider.
content.parserSentence: Examples of patient related tasks include acknowledgement of receipt of a test result forwarded from the provider, or a request to schedule an appointment for a pap smear (based on age and frequency criteria) generated automatically by the EHRS on behalf of the provider.

content.sentence: 1) The system shall maintain a list of tasks.
content.parserSentence: The system shall maintain a list of tasks.

content.sentence: 2) The system shall permit the creation of new tasks.
content.parserSentence: The system shall permit the creation of new tasks.

content.sentence: 3) The system should permit the prioritization of tasks according to the nature of the task itself.
content.parserSentence: The system should permit the prioritization of tasks according to the nature of the task itself.

content.sentence: DC.3.1.1 Clinical  Task Assignment and Routing
content.parserSentence: DC.3.1.1 Clinical  Task Assignment and Routing

content.sentence: Statement: Assignment, delegation possibly and possibly transmission of tasks to the appropriate parties
content.parserSentence: Statement: Assignment, delegation possibly and possibly transmission of tasks to the appropriate parties

content.sentence: Description: Tasks are at all times assigned to at least one user or role for disposition.
content.parserSentence: Description: Tasks are at all times assigned to at least one user or role for disposition.

content.sentence: Whether the task is assignable and to whom the task can be assigned will be determined by the specific needs of care setting.
content.parserSentence: Whether the task is assignable and to whom the task can be assigned will be determined by the specific needs of care setting.

content.sentence: Task-assignment lists help users prioritize and complete assigned tasks.
content.parserSentence: Task-assignment lists help users prioritize and complete assigned tasks.

content.sentence: For example, after receiving orders on multiple patients, the RN should be provided with a list of tasks that have been assigned to him or her.
content.parserSentence: For example, after receiving orders on multiple patients, the RN should be provided with a list of tasks that have been assigned to him or her.

content.sentence: These tasks, (i.e. blood draw) can then be routed to other providers in the ED (i.e. technologist).
content.parserSentence: These tasks, (i.e. blood draw) can then be routed to other providers in the ED (i.e. technologist).

content.sentence: To facilitate workflow, display of tasks by provider is helpful, so that tasks may be routed to providers who are free and available.
content.parserSentence: To facilitate workflow, display of tasks by provider is helpful, so that tasks may be routed to providers who are free and available.

content.sentence: Task creation and assignment may be automated, where appropriate.
content.parserSentence: Task creation and assignment may be automated, where appropriate.

content.sentence: An example of a system-triggered task is when lab results are received electronically; a task to review the result is automatically generated and assigned to the licensed practitioner.
content.parserSentence: An example of a system-triggered task is when lab results are received electronically; a task to review the result is automatically generated and assigned to the licensed practitioner.

content.sentence: Proper task assignment ensures that all tasks are disposed of by the appropriate person or role and allows efficient interaction of entities in the care process.
content.parserSentence: Proper task assignment ensures that all tasks are disposed of by the appropriate person or role and allows efficient interaction of entities in the care process.

content.sentence: 1) The system shall provide the ability for users to create manual clinical tasks.
content.parserSentence: The system shall provide the ability for users to create manual clinical tasks.

content.sentence: 2) The system shall provide the ability to automate clinical task creation.
content.parserSentence: The system shall provide the ability to automate clinical task creation.

content.sentence: 3) The system shall provide the ability to manually modify and update task status (e.g. created, performed, canceled, pended, denied, and resolved).
content.parserSentence: The system shall provide the ability to manually modify and update task status (e.g. created, performed, canceled, pended, denied, and resolved).

content.sentence: 4) The system may provide the ability to automatically modify or update the status of tasks based on workflow rules.
content.parserSentence: The system may provide the ability to automatically modify or update the status of tasks based on workflow rules.

content.sentence: 5) The system should provide the ability to assign, and change the assignment of, tasks to individuals or to clinical roles.
content.parserSentence: The system should provide the ability to assign, and change the assignment of, tasks to individuals or to clinical roles.

content.sentence: 6) The system may provide the ability to manage workflow task routing to multiple individuals or roles in succession possibly and possibly in parallel.
content.parserSentence: The system may provide the ability to manage workflow task routing to multiple individuals or roles in succession possibly and possibly in parallel.

content.sentence: 7) The system should provide the ability to prioritize tasks based on urgency assigned to the task.
content.parserSentence: The system should provide the ability to prioritize tasks based on urgency assigned to the task.

content.sentence: 8) The system may provide the ability to restrict task assignment based on appropriate role as defined by the entity.
content.parserSentence: The system may provide the ability to restrict task assignment based on appropriate role as defined by the entity.

content.sentence: 9) The system may provide the ability to escalate clinical tasks as appropriate to ensure timely completion.
content.parserSentence: The system may provide the ability to escalate clinical tasks as appropriate to ensure timely completion.

content.sentence: 10) The system shall permit the delegation of tasks to one or multiple providers.
content.parserSentence: The system shall permit the delegation of tasks to one or multiple providers.

content.sentence: 11) The system should permit the provider to re-prioritize tasks according to the patient severity, length of stay, task duration, or other criteria.
content.parserSentence: The system should permit the provider to re-prioritize tasks according to the patient severity, length of stay, task duration, or other criteria.

content.sentence: DC.3.1.2 Clinical  Task Linking
content.parserSentence: DC.3.1.2 Clinical  Task Linking

content.sentence: Statement: Linkage of tasks to patients possibly and possibly a relevant part of the electronic health record.
content.parserSentence: Statement: Linkage of tasks to patients possibly and possibly a relevant part of the electronic health record.

content.sentence: Description: Clinical tasks must include information or provide an electronic link to information that is required to complete the task.
content.parserSentence: Description: Clinical tasks must include information or provide an electronic link to information that is required to complete the task.

content.sentence: For example, upon ordering an ECG, two separate tasks are automatically created 1) to obtain and ECG on a particular patient, and 2) for the physician to record an interpretation.
content.parserSentence: For example, upon ordering an ECG, two separate tasks are automatically created 1) to obtain and ECG on a particular patient, and 2) for the physician to record an interpretation.

content.sentence: 1) The system shall provide the ability to link a clinical task to the component of the EHR required to complete the Task.
content.parserSentence: The system shall provide the ability to link a clinical task to the component of the EHR required to complete the Task.

content.sentence: 2) The system shall link each clinical task to a patient, an object in the department (i.e. bed to be cleaned), or a place on the patient’s ED chart.
content.parserSentence: The system shall link each clinical task to a patient, an object in the department (i.e. bed to be cleaned), or a place on the patient’s ED chart.

content.sentence: DC.3.1.3 Clinical  Task Tracking
content.parserSentence: DC.3.1.3 Clinical  Task Tracking

content.sentence: Statement: Track tasks to facilitate monitoring for timely and appropriate completion of each task.
content.parserSentence: Statement: Track tasks to facilitate monitoring for timely and appropriate completion of each task.

content.sentence: Description: In order to reduce the risk of errors during the care process due to missed tasks, the provider is able to view and track un-disposed tasks, current work lists, the status of each task, unassigned tasks or other tasks where a risk of omission exists.
content.parserSentence: Description: In order to reduce the risk of errors during the care process due to missed tasks, the provider is able to view and track un-disposed tasks, current work lists, the status of each task, unassigned tasks or other tasks where a risk of omission exists.

content.sentence: The timeliness of certain tasks can be tracked, and backlogs identified.
content.parserSentence: The timeliness of certain tasks can be tracked, and backlogs identified.

content.sentence: For example, the provider responsible for obtaining ECGs is presented with a list of patients requiring an ECG.
content.parserSentence: For example, the provider responsible for obtaining ECGs is presented with a list of patients requiring an ECG.

content.sentence: Ideally this list should be available to all providers working in the ED so that other provider are able to assist when backlogs occur.
content.parserSentence: Ideally this list should be available to all providers working in the ED so that other provider are able to assist when backlogs occur.

content.sentence: 1) The system shall provide the ability to track the status of tasks.
content.parserSentence: The system shall provide the ability to track the status of tasks.

content.sentence: 2) The system shall provide the ability to notify providers of the status of tasks.
content.parserSentence: The system shall provide the ability to notify providers of the status of tasks.

content.sentence: 3) The system should provide the ability to sort clinical tasks by status.
content.parserSentence: The system should provide the ability to sort clinical tasks by status.

content.sentence: 4) The system may provide the ability to present current clinical tasks as work lists.

content.sentence: 5) The system should provide the ability to define the presentation of clinical task lists.
content.parserSentence: The system should provide the ability to define the presentation of clinical task lists.

content.sentence: 6) The system shall track creation, acknowledgment, and completion of tasks.
content.parserSentence: The system shall track creation, acknowledgment, and completion of tasks.

content.sentence: 7) The system shall display, by provider, an up to date list of tasks to be done.

content.sentence: DC.3.2 Support  Clinical Communication
content.parserSentence: DC.3.2 Support  Clinical Communication

content.sentence: Statement: Manage and Support Communication between Providers.
content.parserSentence: Statement: Manage and Support Communication between Providers.

content.sentence: Description: ED care requires secure communications among various providers: doctors, nurses, pharmacy and laboratory personnel, consultants, etc.
content.parserSentence: Description: ED care requires secure communications among various providers: doctors, nurses, pharmacy and laboratory personnel, consultants, etc.

content.sentence: An effective EDIS should support communication by all participants (outside of the scope of order or task fulfillment) to provide automatic tracking and reporting of this communication.
content.parserSentence: An effective EDIS should support communication by all participants (outside of the scope of order or task fulfillment) to provide automatic tracking and reporting of this communication.

content.sentence: The list of communication participants is determined by the care setting and may change over time.
content.parserSentence: The list of communication participants is determined by the care setting and may change over time.

content.sentence: Because of concerns about scalability of the specification over time, communication participants are not enumerated here because it would limit the possibilities available to each care setting and implementation.
content.parserSentence: Because of concerns about scalability of the specification over time, communication participants are not enumerated here because it would limit the possibilities available to each care setting and implementation.

content.sentence: However, communication between providers and between patients and providers will be supported in all appropriate care settings and across care settings.
content.parserSentence: However, communication between providers and between patients and providers will be supported in all appropriate care settings and across care settings.

content.sentence: Implementation of an EDIS enables new and more effective channels of communication, significantly improving efficiency and patient care.
content.parserSentence: Implementation of an EDIS enables new and more effective channels of communication, significantly improving efficiency and patient care.

content.sentence: The communication functions of the EDIS will eventually change the way participants collaborate and distribute the work of patient care.
content.parserSentence: The communication functions of the EDIS will eventually change the way participants collaborate and distribute the work of patient care.

content.sentence: DC.3.2.1 Support  for Inter-Provider Communication
content.parserSentence: DC.3.2.1 Support  for Inter-Provider Communication

content.sentence: Support secure communication to protect the privacy of information as required by federal or jurisdictional law.

content.sentence: Description: Communication among providers involved in the care process can range from real time communication (for example, fulfillment of an injection while the patient is in the exam room), to asynchronous communication (for example, consult reports between physicians).

content.sentence: The system should provide for both verbal and written communication.

content.sentence: 1) The system shall provide a means to record consultations by providers other than the emergency physician.

content.sentence: Description: When a medication is prescribed, the order is routed to the pharmacy or other intended recipient of pharmacy orders.

content.sentence: This information is used to avoid transcription errors and facilitate detection of potential adverse reactions.

content.sentence: The transmission of prescription data between systems should conform to realm acceptable messaging standards.

content.sentence: As an example, specific standards in the United States include the most recent versions of criteria from Health Level 7 (HL7), X12N, possibly and possibly the National Council for Prescription Drug Programs (NCPDP); and those of the National Electronic Claims Standard (NeCST) in Canada.

content.parserSentence: S.1.4.1 Patient Demographics

content.sentence: An EHR-S must be capable of including or interfacing with standards-conformant security services to ensure that any Principal (user, organization, device , application, component, or object) accessing the system or its data is appropriately authenticated, authorized and audited in conformance with local possibly and possibly jurisdictional policies.
content.parserSentence: An EHR-S must be capable of including or interfacing with standards-conformant security services to ensure that any Principal (user, organization, device , application, component, or object) accessing the system or its data is appropriately authenticated, authorized and audited in conformance with local possibly and possibly jurisdictional policies.

content.sentence: An EHR-S should support Chains of Trust in respect of authentication, authorization, and privilege management, either intrinsically or by interfacing with relevant external services.
content.parserSentence: An EHR-S should support Chains of Trust in respect of authentication, authorization, and privilege management, either intrinsically or by interfacing with relevant external services.

content.sentence: IN.1.1 Entity Authentication
content.parserSentence: IN.1.1 Entity Authentication

content.sentence: Statement:  Authenticate EHR-S users possibly and possibly entities before allowing access to an EHR-S.
content.parserSentence: Statement:  Authenticate EHR-S users possibly and possibly entities before allowing access to an EHR-S.

content.sentence: Description: Both users and applications are subject to authentication.
content.parserSentence: Description: Both users and applications are subject to authentication.

content.sentence: The EHR-S must provide mechanisms for users and applications to be authenticated.
content.parserSentence: The EHR-S must provide mechanisms for users and applications to be authenticated.

content.sentence: Users will have to be authenticated when they attempt to use the application, the applications must authenticate themselves before accessing EHR information managed by other applications or remote EHR-S’.
content.parserSentence: Users will have to be authenticated when they attempt to use the application, the applications must authenticate themselves before accessing EHR information managed by other applications or remote EHR-S’.

content.sentence: In order for authentication to be established a Chain of Trust agreement may need to be in place.
content.parserSentence: In order for authentication to be established a Chain of Trust agreement may need to be in place.

content.sentence: Examples of entity authentication include: Username or  password; Digital certificate; Secure token; Biometrics.
content.parserSentence: Examples of entity authentication include: Username or  password; Digital certificate; Secure token; Biometrics.

content.sentence: 1) The system shall authenticate principals prior to accessing an EHR-S application or EHR-S data.
content.parserSentence: The system shall authenticate principals prior to accessing an EHR-S application or EHR-S data.

content.sentence: 2) The system shall prevent access to EHR-S applications or EHR-S data to all non-authenticated principals.
content.parserSentence: The system shall prevent access to EHR-S applications or EHR-S data to all non-authenticated principals.

content.sentence: 3) The system should provide the ability to implement a Chain of Trust agreement.
content.parserSentence: The system should provide the ability to implement a Chain of Trust agreement.

content.sentence: 4) In the absence of other appropriate authentication mechanisms, the system shall authenticate principals using at least one of the following authentication mechanisms: username or password, digital certificate, secure token or biometrics.
content.parserSentence: In the absence of other appropriate authentication mechanisms, the system shall authenticate principals using at least one of the following authentication mechanisms: username or password, digital certificate, secure token or biometrics.

content.sentence: IN.1.2 Entity Authorization
content.parserSentence: IN.1.2 Entity Authorization

content.sentence: Statement:  Manage the sets of access control permissions granted to entities that use an EHR-S (EHR-S Users).
content.parserSentence: Statement:  Manage the sets of access control permissions granted to entities that use an EHR-S (EHR-S Users).

content.sentence: Enable EHR-S security administrators to grant authorizations to users, for roles, and within contexts.
content.parserSentence: Enable EHR-S security administrators to grant authorizations to users, for roles, and within contexts.

content.sentence: A combination of these authorization categories may be applied to control access to EHR-S functions or data within an EHR-S, including at the application or the operating system level.
content.parserSentence: A combination of these authorization categories may be applied to control access to EHR-S functions or data within an EHR-S, including at the application or the operating system level.

content.sentence: Description: EHR-S Users are authorized to use the components of an EHR-S according to their identity, role, work-assignment, location possibly and possibly the patient’s present condition and the EHR-S User’s scope of practice within a  legal jurisdiction.
content.parserSentence: Description: EHR-S Users are authorized to use the components of an EHR-S according to their identity, role, work-assignment, location possibly and possibly the patient’s present condition and the EHR-S User’s scope of practice within a  legal jurisdiction.

content.sentence: • User based authorization refers to the permissions granted or denied based on the identity of an individual.
content.parserSentence: User based authorization refers to the permissions granted or denied based on the identity of an individual.

content.sentence: An example of User based authorization is a patient defined denial of access to all or part of a record to a particular party for privacy related reasons.
content.parserSentence: An example of User based authorization is a patient defined denial of access to all or part of a record to a particular party for privacy related reasons.

content.sentence: Another user based authorization is for a tele-monitor device or robotic access to an EHR-S for prescribed directions and other input.
content.parserSentence: Another user based authorization is for a tele-monitor device or robotic access to an EHR-S for prescribed directions and other input.

content.sentence: • Role based authorization refers to the responsibility or function performed in a particular operation or process.
content.parserSentence: Role based authorization refers to the responsibility or function performed in a particular operation or process.

content.sentence: Example roles include: an application or device (tele-monitor or robotic); or a nurse, dietician, administrator, legal guardian, and auditor.
content.parserSentence: Example roles include: an application or device (tele-monitor or robotic); or a nurse, dietician, administrator, legal guardian, and auditor.

content.sentence: • Context-based Authorization is defined by ISO 10181-3
content.parserSentence: Context-based Authorization is defined by ISO 10181-3

content.sentence: Technical Framework for Access Control Standard as security relevant properties of the context in which an access request occurs, explicitly time, location, route of access, and quality of authentication.
content.parserSentence: Technical Framework for Access Control Standard as security relevant properties of the context in which an access request occurs, explicitly time, location, route of access, and quality of authentication.

content.sentence: For example, an EHR-S might only allow supervising providers’ context authorization to attest to entries proposed by residents under their supervision.
content.parserSentence: For example, an EHR-S might only allow supervising providers’ context authorization to attest to entries proposed by residents under their supervision.

content.sentence: In addition to the ISO standard, context authorization for an EHR-S is extended to satisfy special circumstances such as, work assignment, patient consents and authorizations, or other healthcare-related factors.
content.parserSentence: In addition to the ISO standard, context authorization for an EHR-S is extended to satisfy special circumstances such as, work assignment, patient consents and authorizations, or other healthcare-related factors.
content.comments: since there no action, no logging.

content.sentence: A context-based example is a patient-granted authorization to a specific third party for a limited period to view specific EHR records.
content.parserSentence: A context-based example is a patient-granted authorization to a specific third party for a limited period to view specific EHR records.

content.sentence: Another example is a right granted for a limited period to view those, and only those, EHR records connected to a specific topic of investigation.
content.parserSentence: Another example is a right granted for a limited period to view those, and only those, EHR records connected to a specific topic of investigation.

content.sentence: 1) The system shall provide the ability to create and update of sets of access-control permissions granted to principals.
content.parserSentence: The system shall provide the ability to create and update of sets of access-control permissions granted to principals.

content.sentence: 2) The system shall conform to function IN.2.2 (Auditable Records) for the purpose of recording all authorization actions.
content.parserSentence: The system shall conform to function IN.2.2 (Auditable Records) for the purpose of recording all authorization actions.

content.sentence: 3) The system shall provide EHR-S security administrators with the ability to grant authorizations to principals according to scope of practice, organizational policy, or jurisdictional law.
content.parserSentence: The system shall provide EHR-S security administrators with the ability to grant authorizations to principals according to scope of practice, organizational policy, or jurisdictional law.

content.sentence: 4) The system shall provide EHR-S security administrators with the ability to grant authorizations for roles according to scope of practice, organizational policy, or jurisdictional law.
content.parserSentence: The system shall provide EHR-S security administrators with the ability to grant authorizations for roles according to scope of practice, organizational policy, or jurisdictional law.

content.sentence: 5) The system shall provide EHR-S security administrators with the ability to grant authorizations within contexts according to scope of practice, organizational policy, or jurisdictional law.
content.parserSentence: The system shall provide EHR-S security administrators with the ability to grant authorizations within contexts according to scope of practice, organizational policy, or jurisdictional law.

content.sentence: 6) The system may provide the ability to define context for the purpose of principal authorization based on identity, role, work assignment, present condition, location, patient consent, or patient’s present condition.
content.parserSentence: The system may provide the ability to define context for the purpose of principal authorization based on identity, role, work assignment, present condition, location, patient consent, or patient’s present condition.

content.sentence: 7) The system may provide the ability to define context based on legal requirements or disaster conditions.
content.parserSentence: The system may provide the ability to define context based on legal requirements or disaster conditions.

content.sentence: IN.1.3 Entity Access Control
content.parserSentence: IN.1.3 Entity Access Control

content.sentence: Statement:  Verify and enforce access control to all EHR-S components, EHR information and functions for end-users, applications, sites, etc., to prevent unauthorized use of a resource.
content.parserSentence: Statement:  Verify and enforce access control to all EHR-S components, EHR information and functions for end-users, applications, sites, etc., to prevent unauthorized use of a resource.

content.sentence: Description: Entity Access Control is a fundamental function of an EHR-S.
content.parserSentence: Description: Entity Access Control is a fundamental function of an EHR-S.
content.comments: no specific requirement.

content.sentence: To ensure that access is controlled, an EHR-S must perform authentication and authorization of users or applications for any operation that requires it and enforce the system and information access rules that have been defined.
content.parserSentence: To ensure that access is controlled, an EHR-S must perform authentication and authorization of users or applications for any operation that requires it and enforce the system and information access rules that have been defined.

content.sentence: 1) The system shall conform to function IN.1.1 (Entity Authentication).
content.parserSentence: The system shall conform to function IN.1.1 (Entity Authentication).

content.sentence: 2) The system shall conform to function IN.1.2 (Entity Authorization).
content.parserSentence: The system shall conform to function IN.1.2 (Entity Authorization).

content.sentence: 3) The system shall provide the ability to define system and data access rules.
content.parserSentence: The system shall provide the ability to define system and data access rules.

content.sentence: 4) The system shall enforce system and data access rules for all EHR-S resources (at component, application, or user level, either local or remote).
content.parserSentence: The system shall enforce system and data access rules for all EHR-S resources (at component, application, or user level, either local or remote).

content.sentence: IN.1.5 Non-repudiation
content.parserSentence: IN.1.5 Non-repudiation

content.sentence: Statement:  Limit an EHR-S user’s ability to deny (repudiate) the origination, receipt, or authorization of a data exchange by that user.
content.parserSentence: Statement:  Limit an EHR-S user’s ability to deny (repudiate) the origination, receipt, or authorization of a data exchange by that user.

content.sentence: Description: An EHR-S allows data entry and data access to a patient's electronic health record and it can be a sender or receiver of healthcare information.
content.parserSentence: Description: An EHR-S allows data entry and data access to a patient's electronic health record and it can be a sender or receiver of healthcare information.

content.sentence: Non repudiation guarantees that the source of the data record can not later deny that it is the source; that the sender or receiver of a message cannot later deny having sent or received the message.
content.parserSentence: Non repudiation guarantees that the source of the data record can not later deny that it is the source; that the sender or receiver of a message cannot later deny having sent or received the message.
content.comments: definition of non-repudiation.  not a requirment.

content.sentence: An EHR-S allows data entry and data access to a patient’s electronic health record, and it can be a sender of healthcare information, and a receiver of healthcare information.
content.parserSentence: An EHR-S allows data entry and data access to a patient’s electronic health record, and it can be a sender of healthcare information, and a receiver of healthcare information.

content.sentence: Non-repudiation is a way to guarantee that the source of data or record can not later deny that fact, that the sender of a message cannot later deny having sent the message, and that the recipient cannot deny having received the message.
content.parserSentence: Non-repudiation is a way to guarantee that the source of data or record can not later deny that fact, that the sender of a message cannot later deny having sent the message, and that the recipient cannot deny having received the message.

content.sentence: For example, non-repudiation may be achieved through the use of a:
content.parserSentence: For example, non-repudiation may be achieved through the use of a:

content.sentence: • Digital signature, which serves as a unique identifier for an individual (much like a written signature on a paper document).
content.parserSentence: For example, non-repudiation may be achieved through the use of a: Digital signature, which serves as a unique identifier for an individual (much like a written signature on a paper document).

content.sentence: • Confirmation service, which utilizes a message transfer agent to create a digital receipt (providing confirmation that a message was sent possibly and possibly received) and
content.parserSentence: For example, non-repudiation may be achieved through the use of a: Confirmation service, which utilizes a message transfer agent to create a digital receipt (providing confirmation that a message was sent possibly and possibly received) and

content.sentence: • Timestamp, which proves that a document existed at a certain date and time.
content.parserSentence: For example, non-repudiation may be achieved through the use of a: Timestamp, which proves that a document existed at a certain date and time.

content.sentence: 1) The system shall time stamp initial entry, modification, or exchange of data, and identify the actor or principal taking the action as required by users' scope of practice, organizational policy, or jurisdictional law.
content.parserSentence: The system shall time stamp initial entry, modification, or exchange of data, and identify the actor or principal taking the action as required by users' scope of practice, organizational policy, or jurisdictional law.

content.sentence: 2) The system shall provide additional non-repudiation functionality where required by users' scope of practice, organizational policy, or jurisdictional law.

content.sentence: 3) The system should conform to function IN.2.2 (Auditable Records) to prevent repudiation of data origination, receipt, or access.

content.sentence: 4) The system should conform to function IN.1.8 (Information Attestation) to ensure the integrity of data exchange and thus prevent repudiation of data origination or receipt.

content.sentence: IN.1.6 Secure Data Exchange
content.parserSentence: IN.1.6 Secure Data Exchange

content.sentence: Statement:  Secure all modes of EHR data exchange.
content.parserSentence: Statement:  Secure all modes of EHR data exchange.

content.sentence: Description: Whenever an exchange of EHR information occurs, it requires appropriate security and privacy considerations, including data obfuscation as well as both destination and source authentication when necessary.
content.parserSentence: Description: Whenever an exchange of EHR information occurs, it requires appropriate security and privacy considerations, including data obfuscation as well as both destination and source authentication when necessary.

content.sentence: For example, it may be necessary to encrypt data sent to remote or external destinations.
content.parserSentence: For example, it may be necessary to encrypt data sent to remote or external destinations.

content.sentence: A secure data exchange requires that there is an overall coordination regarding the information coordination regarding the information that is exchanged between EHR-S entities and how that exchange is expected to occur.
content.parserSentence: A secure data exchange requires that there is an overall coordination regarding the information coordination regarding the information that is exchanged between EHR-S entities and how that exchange is expected to occur.

content.sentence: The policies applied at different locations must be consistent or compatible with each other in order to ensure that the information is protected when it crosses entity boundaries within an EHR-S or external to an EHR-S.
content.parserSentence: The policies applied at different locations must be consistent or compatible with each other in order to ensure that the information is protected when it crosses entity boundaries within an EHR-S or external to an EHR-S.

content.sentence: 1) The system shall secure all modes of EHR data exchange.
content.parserSentence: The system shall secure all modes of EHR data exchange.

content.sentence: 2) The system should conform to function IN.1.7 (Secure Data Routing).
content.parserSentence: The system should conform to function IN.1.7 (Secure Data Routing).

content.sentence: 3) The system may provide the ability to obfuscate data.
content.parserSentence: The system may provide the ability to obfuscate data.

content.sentence: 4) The system shall encrypt and decrypt EHR data that is exchanged over a non-secure link.
content.parserSentence: The system shall encrypt and decrypt EHR data that is exchanged over a non-secure link.

content.sentence: 5) The system shall support standards-based encryption mechanisms when encryption is used for secure data exchange.

content.sentence: Secure Data Routing
content.parserSentence: Secure Data Routing

content.sentence: Statement:  Route electronically exchanged EHR data only to or from known, registered, and authenticated destinations or sources (according to applicable healthcare-specific rules and relevant standards).
content.parserSentence: Statement:  Route electronically exchanged EHR data only to or from known, registered, and authenticated destinations or sources (according to applicable healthcare-specific rules and relevant standards).

content.sentence: Description: An EHR-S needs to ensure that it is exchanging EHR information with the entities (applications, institutions, directories) it expects.
content.parserSentence: Description: An EHR-S needs to ensure that it is exchanging EHR information with the entities (applications, institutions, directories) it expects.

content.sentence: This function depends on entity authorization and authentication to be available in the system.
content.parserSentence: This function depends on entity authorization and authentication to be available in the system.

content.sentence: For example, a physician practice management application in an EHR-S might send claim attachment information to an external entity.
content.parserSentence: For example, a physician practice management application in an EHR-S might send claim attachment information to an external entity.

content.sentence: To accomplish this, the application must use a secure routing method, which ensures that both the sender and receiving sides are authorized to engage in the information exchange.
content.parserSentence: To accomplish this, the application must use a secure routing method, which ensures that both the sender and receiving sides are authorized to engage in the information exchange.

content.sentence: Known sources and destinations can be established in a static setup or they can be dynamically determined.
content.parserSentence: Known sources and destinations can be established in a static setup or they can be dynamically determined.

content.sentence: Examples of a static setup are recordings of IP addresses or recordings of DNS names.
content.parserSentence: Examples of a static setup are recordings of IP addresses or recordings of DNS names.

content.sentence: For dynamic determination of known sources and destinations systems can use authentication mechanisms as described in IN.1.1.
content.parserSentence: For dynamic determination of known sources and destinations systems can use authentication mechanisms as described in IN.1.1.

content.sentence: For example, the sending of a lab order from the EHR-S to a lab system within the same organization usually uses a simple static setup for routing.
content.parserSentence: For example, the sending of a lab order from the EHR-S to a lab system within the same organization usually uses a simple static setup for routing.

content.sentence: In contrast sending a lab order to a reference lab outside of the organization will involve some kind of authentication process.
content.parserSentence: In contrast sending a lab order to a reference lab outside of the organization will involve some kind of authentication process.

content.sentence: In general, when the underlying network infrastructure is secure (e.g. secure LAN or VPN) the simple static setup is used.
content.parserSentence: In general, when the underlying network infrastructure is secure (e.g. secure LAN or VPN) the simple static setup is used.

content.sentence: 1) The system shall automatically route electronically exchanged EHR data only from and to known sources and destinations and only over secure networks.
content.parserSentence: The system shall automatically route electronically exchanged EHR data only from and to known sources and destinations and only over secure networks.

content.sentence: 2) The system shall route electronically exchanged EHR data only to and from authenticated sources and destinations (conform to function IN.1.1 (Entity Authentication).
content.parserSentence: The system shall route electronically exchanged EHR data only to and from authenticated sources and destinations (conform to function IN.1.1 (Entity Authentication).

content.sentence: 3) The system should conform to function IN.2.2 (Auditable Records) to provide audit information about additions and changes to the status of destinations and sources
content.parserSentence: The system should conform to function IN.2.2 (Auditable Records) to provide audit information about additions and changes to the status of destinations and sources

content.sentence: IN.1.8 Information Attestation
content.parserSentence: IN.1.8 Information Attestation

content.sentence: Statement:  Manage electronic attestation of information including the retention of the signature of attestation (or certificate of authenticity) associated with incoming or outgoing information.
content.parserSentence: Statement:  Manage electronic attestation of information including the retention of the signature of attestation (or certificate of authenticity) associated with incoming or outgoing information.

content.sentence: Description: The purpose of attestation is to show authorship and assign responsibility for an act, event, condition, opinion, or diagnosis.
content.parserSentence: Description: The purpose of attestation is to show authorship and assign responsibility for an act, event, condition, opinion, or diagnosis.

content.sentence: Every entry in the health record must be identified with the author and should not be made or signed by someone other than the author.
content.parserSentence: Every entry in the health record must be identified with the author and should not be made or signed by someone other than the author.

content.sentence: (Note: A transcriptionist may transcribe an author's notes and a senior clinician may attest to the accuracy of another's statement of events.)

content.sentence: Digital signatures may be used to implement document attestation.

content.sentence: For an incoming document, the record of attestation is retained if included.

content.sentence: Attestation functionality must meet applicable legal, regulatory and other applicable standards or requirements.

content.sentence: 3) The system shall provide the ability to associate any attestable content added or changed to an EHR with the content's author (for example by conforming to function IN.2.2 (Auditable Records)).

content.sentence: IN.1.9 Patient Privacy and Confidentiality
content.parserSentence: IN.1.9 Patient Privacy and Confidentiality

content.sentence: Statement:  Enable the enforcement of the applicable jurisdictional and organizational patient privacy rules as they apply to various parts of an EHR-S through the implementation of security mechanisms.
content.parserSentence: Statement:  Enable the enforcement of the applicable jurisdictional and organizational patient privacy rules as they apply to various parts of an EHR-S through the implementation of security mechanisms.

content.sentence: Description: Patients’ privacy and the confidentiality of EHRs are violated if access to EHRs occurs without authorization.
content.parserSentence: Description: Patients’ privacy and the confidentiality of EHRs are violated if access to EHRs occurs without authorization.

content.sentence: Violations or potential violations can impose tangible economic or social losses on affected patients and providers, as well as less tangible feelings of vulnerability and pain.

content.sentence: Fear of potential violations discourages patients from revealing sensitive personal information that may be relevant to diagnostic and treatment services.

content.sentence: Rules for the protection of privacy and confidentiality may vary depending upon the vulnerability of patients and the sensitivity of records.

content.sentence: Strongest protections should apply to the records of minors and the records of patients with stigmatized conditions.
content.parserSentence: Strongest protections should apply to the records of minors and the records of patients with stigmatized conditions.

content.sentence: Authorization to access the most sensitive parts of an EHR is most definitive if made by the explicit and specific consent of the patient.
content.parserSentence: Authorization to access the most sensitive parts of an EHR is most definitive if made by the explicit and specific consent of the patient.

content.sentence: 6) The system shall conform to function IN.1.6 (Secure DataExchange).

content.sentence: IN.2 Health Record Information and Management
content.parserSentence: IN.2 Health Record Information and Management

content.sentence: Statement:  Manage EHR information across EHR-S applications by ensuring that clinical information entered by providers is a valid representation of clinical notes; and is accurate and complete according to clinical rules and tracking amendments to clinical documents.
content.parserSentence: Statement:  Manage EHR information across EHR-S applications by ensuring that clinical information entered by providers is a valid representation of clinical notes; and is accurate and complete according to clinical rules and tracking amendments to clinical documents.

content.sentence: Ensure that information entered by or on behalf of the patient is accurately represented.
content.parserSentence: Ensure that information entered by or on behalf of the patient is accurately represented.

content.sentence: Description: Since EHR information will typically be available on a variety of EHRS applications, an EHR-S must provide the ability to access, manage and verify accuracy and completeness of EHR information, maintain the integrity and reliability of the data, and provide the ability to audit the use of and access to EHR information.
content.parserSentence: Description: Since EHR information will typically be available on a variety of EHRS applications, an EHR-S must provide the ability to access, manage and verify accuracy and completeness of EHR information, maintain the integrity and reliability of the data, and provide the ability to audit the use of and access to EHR information.

content.sentence: IN.2.1 Data Retention  Availability and Destruction
content.parserSentence: IN.2.1 Data Retention  Availability and Destruction

content.sentence: Statement:  Retain, ensure availability, and destroy health record information according to scope of practice, organizational policy, or jurisdictional law.
content.parserSentence: Statement:  Retain, ensure availability, and destroy health record information according to scope of practice, organizational policy, or jurisdictional law.

content.sentence: This includes: - Retaining all EHR-S data and clinical documents for the time period designated by policy or legal requirement; -Retaining inbound documents as originally received (unaltered); - Ensuring availability of information for the legally prescribed period of time to users and patients; and -Providing the ability to destroy EHR data or records in a systematic way according to policy and after the legally prescribed retention period.
content.parserSentence: This includes: - Retaining all EHR-S data and clinical documents for the time period designated by policy or legal requirement; -Retaining inbound documents as originally received (unaltered); - Ensuring availability of information for the legally prescribed period of time to users and patients; and -Providing the ability to destroy EHR data or records in a systematic way according to policy and after the legally prescribed retention period.

content.sentence: Description: Discrete and structured EHR-S data, records and reports must be: -Made available to users in a timely fashion; - Stored and retrieved in a semantically intelligent and useful manner (for example, chronologically, retrospectively per a given disease or event, or in accordance with business requirements, local policies, or legal requirements); -Retained for a legally prescribed period of time; and -Destroyed in a systematic manner in relation to the applicable retention period.
content.parserSentence: Description: Discrete and structured EHR-S data, records and reports must be: -Made available to users in a timely fashion; - Stored and retrieved in a semantically intelligent and useful manner (for example, chronologically, retrospectively per a given disease or event, or in accordance with business requirements, local policies, or legal requirements); -Retained for a legally prescribed period of time; and -Destroyed in a systematic manner in relation to the applicable retention period.

content.sentence: An EHR-S must also allow an organization to identify data or records to be destroyed, and to review and approve destruction before it occurs.
content.parserSentence: An EHR-S must also allow an organization to identify data or records to be destroyed, and to review and approve destruction before it occurs.

content.sentence: 1) The system shall provide the ability to store and retrieve health record data and clinical documents for the legally prescribed time.

content.sentence: 2) The system shall provide the ability to retain inbound data or documents (related to health records) as originally received (unaltered, inclusive of the method in which they were received) for the legally organizationally prescribed time in accordance with users’ scope of practice, organizational policy, or jurisdictional law.

content.sentence: IN.2.2 Auditable Records
content.parserSentence: IN.2.2 Auditable Records

content.sentence: Statement:  Provide audit capabilities for system access and usage indicating the author, the modification (where pertinent), and the date and time at which a record was created, modified, viewed, extracted, or deleted.

content.parserSentence: Audit functionality includes the ability to generate audit reports and to interactively generate audit reports and to interactively view change history for individual health records or for an EHR-S

content.sentence: Audit capability settings should be configurable to meet the needs of local policies.

content.sentence: Examples of audited areas include:

content.sentence: • Security audit, which logs access attempts and resource usage including user login, file access, other various activities, and whether any actual or attempted security violations occurred;

content.sentence: • Data audit, which records who, when, and by which system an EHR record was created, updated, translated, viewed, extracted, or (if local policy permits) deleted.

content.sentence: • Information exchange audit, which records data exchanges between EHR-S applications (for example, sending application; the nature, history, and content of the information exchanged); and information about data transformations (for example, vocabulary translations, reception event details, etc.).

content.sentence: Synchronization
content.parserSentence: Synchronization

content.sentence: Statement:  Maintain synchronization involving:
content.parserSentence: Statement:  Maintain synchronization involving:

content.sentence: -Interaction with entity directories;
content.parserSentence: -Interaction with entity directories;

content.sentence: -Linkage of received data with existing entity records;
content.parserSentence: -Linkage of received data with existing entity records;

content.sentence: -Location of each health record component; and
content.parserSentence: -Location of each health record component; and

content.sentence: -Communication of changes between key systems.
content.parserSentence: -Communication of changes between key systems.

content.sentence: Description: An EHR-S may consist of a set of components or applications; each application manages a subset of the health information.
content.parserSentence: Description: An EHR-S may consist of a set of components or applications; each application manages a subset of the health information.

content.sentence: Therefore it is important that, through various interoperability mechanisms, an EHR-S maintains all the relevant information regarding the health record in synchrony.
content.parserSentence: Therefore it is important that, through various interoperability mechanisms, an EHR-S maintains all the relevant information regarding the health record in synchrony.

content.sentence: For example, if a physician orders an MRI, a set of diagnostic images and a radiology report will be created.
content.parserSentence: For example, if a physician orders an MRI, a set of diagnostic images and a radiology report will be created.

content.sentence: The patient demographics, the order for MRI, the diagnostic images associated with the order, and the report associated with the study must all be synchronized in order for the clinicians to view the complete record.
content.parserSentence: The patient demographics, the order for MRI, the diagnostic images associated with the order, and the report associated with the study must all be synchronized in order for the clinicians to view the complete record.

content.sentence: 1) The system shall conform to function IN.5.1 (Interchange Standards).
content.parserSentence: The system shall conform to function IN.5.1 (Interchange Standards).

content.sentence: 2) The system should conform to function IN.3 (Registry and Directory Services) to enable the use of registries and directories.
content.parserSentence: The system should conform to function IN.3 (Registry and Directory Services) to enable the use of registries and directories.

content.sentence: 3) The system should provide the ability to link entities to external information.
content.parserSentence: The system should provide the ability to link entities to external information.

content.sentence: 4) The system should store the location of each known health record component in order to enable authorized access to a complete logical health record if the EHR is distributed among several applications within the EHR-S.

content.sentence: Description: An EHR-S enables an authorized user, such as a clinician, to access and aggregate the distributed information, which corresponds to the health record or records that are needed for viewing, reporting, disclosure, etc.

content.sentence: An EHR-S must support data extraction operations across the complete data set that constitutes the health record of an individual and provide an output that fully chronicles the healthcare process.
content.parserSentence: An EHR-S must support data extraction operations across the complete data set that constitutes the health record of an individual and provide an output that fully chronicles the healthcare process.

content.sentence: Data extractions are used as input to patient care coordination between facilities, organizations and settings.

content.sentence: In addition, data extractions can be used for administrative, financial, research, quality analysis, and public health purposes.

content.sentence: IN.4.1 Standard Terminologies and Terminology Models
content.parserSentence: IN.4.1 Standard Terminologies and Terminology Models

content.sentence: Statement:  Employ standard terminologies to ensure data correctness and to enable semantic interoperability (both within an enterprise and externally).

content.sentence: Support a formal standard terminology model.

content.sentence: Description: Semantic interoperability requires standard terminologies combined with a formal standard information model.

content.sentence: An example of an information model is the HL7 Reference Information model.

content.sentence: Examples of terminologies that an EHR-S may support include: LOINC, SNOMED, ICD-9, ICD-10, and CPT-4.

content.sentence: A terminology provides semantic and computable identity to its concepts.

content.sentence: Terminologies are use-case dependent and may or may not be realm dependent.

content.sentence: For example, terminologies for public health interoperability may differ from those for healthcare quality, administrative reporting, research, etc.
content.parserSentence: For example, terminologies for public health interoperability may differ from those for healthcare quality, administrative reporting, research, etc.

content.sentence: Formal standard terminology models enable common semantic representations by describing relationships that exist between concepts within a terminology or in different terminologies, such as exemplified in the model descriptions contained in the HL7 Common Terminology Services specification.

content.sentence: The clinical use of standard terminologies is greatly enhanced with the ability to perform hierarchical inference searches across coded concepts.

content.sentence: Hierarchical Inference enables searches to be conducted across sets of coded concepts stored in an EHR-S.

content.sentence: Relationships between concepts in the terminology are between concepts in the terminology are used in the search to recognize child concepts of a common parent.

content.sentence: For example, there may be a parent concept, "penicillin containing preparations" which has numerous child concepts, each of which represents a preparation containing a specific form of penicillin (Penicillin V, Penicillin G, etc).
content.parserSentence: For example, there may be a parent concept, "penicillin containing preparations" which has numerous child concepts, each of which represents a preparation containing a specific form of penicillin (Penicillin V, Penicillin G, etc).

content.sentence: Therefore, a search may be conducted to find all patients taking any form of penicillin preparation.
